content: Uri Wilensky Projects Publications NetLogo NetLogo home Resources Media Mentions Press Educational Resources People Jobs The Center for Connected Learning and Computer-Based Modeling Uri Wilensky - CCL Director Uri Wilensky is the Lorraine H. Morton professor of Learning Sciences, Computer Science and Complex Systems at Northwestern University. He is the co-director of the joint PHD program in Computer Science and Learning Sciences (CSLS) . He is the author of the award-winning NetLogo agent-based modeling software, which his lab actively maintains and improves. It is the most widely used agent-based modeling software, and has hundreds of thousands of users worldwide using it for both research and education. Wilensky has published more than 300 scientific articles and more than 500 agent-based models. Wilensky is a fellow of the National Academy of Education and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. He is the founder and current director of the Center for Connected Learning and Computer-Based Modeling(CCL) and a co-founder of the Northwestern Institute on Complex Systems(NICO). He is also a faculty member (by courtesy) in Cognitive Science, Philosophy, the program in Technology and Social Behavior, and the Segal Design Center research council. Wilensky has received numerous awards, including the 2025 Yidan Prize for educational research, the NSF career award, and the 2016 ISDDE prize for excellence in design for his work on NetLogo.
